content:
This is a nice clash, but needs more test cases.

Particularly there's not enough good tests for the range sum.

I got 100% on the tests in-clash, but then only 75% on validators. I failed Validator 1, particularly the 's 2 3' part.

My code mistakenly did the range sum from A_l to A_(l+r) instead of to A_r. I didn't notice the mistake in-clash, because the tests all passed even with my mistake.

Ruby code below

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: La description est claire et bien structurée, les opérations (+, ?, s) sont expliquées sans ambiguïté et les indices sont correctement définis comme 1-based.
Les jeux de tests couvrent les différents cas possibles : sommes simples, mises à jour ponctuelles, valeurs négatives, bornes, et cas où les mises à jour s’annulent (somme = 0).
Le puzzle reste rapide à résoudre (< 5 min) avec une solution directe utilisant des opérations de tableau simples, conforme à l’objectif annoncé.
J’ai validé la solution moi-même, elle fonctionne parfaitement avec tous les tests fournis.

Interesting edge case: the total becomes 0 after opposite updates cancel each other out.
Example:
3 5
2 -1 -1
? 3
+ 2 1
+ 3 -1
s 1 3
? 2
Expected output:
0
0
2

Explanation:
Initial array: [2, -1, -1] → ? 3 → 2 + (-1) + (-1) = 0
After + 2 1: [2, 0, -1]
After + 3 -1: [2, 0, -2]
s 1 3 → 2 + 0 + (-2) = 0 (sum canceled out)
? 2 → 2 + 0 = 2

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est une manipulation élémentaire mais intéressante d'une liste de taille finie, qui peut se résoudre très facilement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was fun, and just the right difficulty level for a CoC.

Goal
* I wrote a short straightforward solution which could pass all the existing cases, without any optimisation for large inputs, because there aren't such cases. The statement hints at the need for a Binary Indexed Tree (Fenwick Tree), and that's misleading.

Since a clash of code is a short timed challenge, the current cases are fine, while requiring a complex data structure isn't suitable. Would you please rewrite the statement and remove the hint, because efficiency beyond simple array operations isn't necessary for the scope of this task?

* "Growing log": misleading; the array size is fixed (N) and doesn't grow.

* "Counters": these are array elements, not counters.

* "Events": the statement should consistently refer to "operations" (used in the Input section) rather than "events".

* Please add "Indices are <<1-based>>" after the first sentence.

Formatting
* Refer to the explanation and follow the example in the link for formatting and presenting the various sections: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement . Below are more specific points:

* Goal / Input / Constraints: Please format "A", "N", "Q", "i", "r", "l" and "v" as [[variables]].

* Input / Output: Please format "+", "?" and "s" as {{constants}}.

* Input: Please format "Line 1", "Line 2" and "Next [[Q]] lines" in <<bold>>.

Input
* Line 1
  • "counters": See comment on "counters" above.
  
  • Please add "space-separated" between "two" and "integers".

* Line 2
  • Please add "space-separated" between "[[N]]" and "integers".

  • Please add "elements of the" before "initial".

* Please delete all the inequalities in this section.

Constraints
* Please change 200 000 to 10.

* Please delete constraints 2 to 4.

* Please add the following constraints:
-100 ≤ [[v]], element in [[A]] ≤ 100
1 ≤ [[i]] ≤ [[N]]
1 ≤ [[l]] ≤ [[r]] ≤ [[N]]

Cases
* Please change some of the validators so that [[l]] ≠ 1.

* Validator 1: Please create a new pair of cases, with Test 5 being a copy of Validator 1, and Validator 5 featuring another 1-element array. Then create a new Validator 1 similar to Test 1 to pair with it.

Thanks.

n, q = gets.split.map { |x| x.to_i }
a = gets.split.map(&:to_i)
q.times do
  op = gets.split
  t = op[0]
  x = op[1..].map(&:to_i)
  u, v = x
  if t == "+"
    a[u-1] += v
  elsif t == "?"
    puts a[0, u].sum
  else
    puts a[u-1...u+v].sum    # The erroneous line
  end
end
@5DN1L Would appreciate your review of the updated version.

It's much better now. To improve readability, consider replacing the current notations in the Goal and Input sections with the following ones:

[[A₁]]
[[Aᵢ]]
[[Aₗ]]
[[Aᵣ]]

Thanks.
